body.p:
Your esteemed favors p Mr Nathans. and p mail
16th met on at hand. Euripides says.
body.quote: “The Wise with hope, support the pains of life.”
body.p:
Not to quote the number less passages from scripture where
the same lesson is inculcated. take consolation my good sir.
and do not despond—I see through the thin vapour which
is insufficient to obscure the brightness of the orb beyond.
And as I do not possess more keenery of vision than
the rest of the community who use these eyes, without
the use of yellow or green glasses. depend upon it Caesar will get
his due in proper time, only for the future bear in mind
the quotation from Horace Epistles XVIII.36..lib1.
body.quote:
“command not, till a man is thoroughly known
Qualem commendes etiam atque etiam adspice, ne
a rascal trained, you make his fault your own
mox, Incutiant aliena tibi peccata pudorem.”
body.p:
What you could not do less than give Mr Myer such a
letter as you have described and which agrees with the
original. Seen by Mr Moise, I am perfectly satisfied and
so is Mr Moise, There is no doubt but it made a
favorable impression altho it did not speak of his religious
principles—which ave developed in a letter to Mr Poznanski
his belief in the bible subject to criticism—and that it also
contains, “Myths”—I suppose from mythos, “fables
a fine teacher in Isaul, who is to select the
fables from the Truths, I should like to get hold of
a copy of the letter, to send to you for publication. These
ought to be a standard for Jewish belief if it is only

compized in only a full faith in the Bible. If a man
cannot fully subscribe to this, he is not fit to be a teacher
in Israel. I do not think that all these things
being known you would have given him the paper,
Resolutions were passed at the meeting on Sunday that
if the Gent came on they would be happy to see him
but made no appropriation to pay his expenses, or
in other words a left handed sort of way of insiting him
on to take a look at the animal, without incurring
any expence—I have not heard if he will come,—
whenever I hear this letter of yours spoken of I shall
take the pains to set you right before the public,
It is not a parrellel care with Dr Raphael. do not
let this worry you. take things coolly,—

with regard to Mr Henry since I wrote you I learned
that Rev Ellis Lyons had recd a letter from Henry. Requesting
Lyons to give him the names in full of such persons who
know any thing about the affair. Mr Valentine tells me
this and also that they wanted his name which he gave at
the same time stating that he knew nothing at all about
the matter. Sam Hart Sr says if they call on him by
commission. he knows nothing and if he did know he would
not say—as he is not compelled to testify out of the state
I shall see Mr Levin to day and get some particulars about it
Mrs Carter thinks you have done wrong and she uses this
argument,—”If Mr Henry “poor man” were not basely slandered
would he ? Mr Leeser and have all the particulars before
the public. I am sure he is innocent.” Now this pretended
production is only got up to create Sympathy for the

poor man, “who came here to sell his books to support his
family.”—the public are not to know that the suit is not
brought,—they learnd that he intends or has sued you
which he would not do if he could not prove his innocence,

When I see Mr Levin I will learn the truth about the
summons. The Lawyer for Henry is also known here.
Your friend Henry Phillips is the man, this is also to give
plausibily to the report—now it may be true but I
do not believe that he will bring suit, and if he does
not—where does Mr Henry stand, if he is innocent
I am sure you will do him justice,

with regard to yourself you are (being a public man)
free game for all to shoot at; and at same time you
have the full privilege to clothe your self in such
a panoply of virtue that the shafts are turned harmless
away. “For those are hated that exel the most
Altho when dead the are beloved, and blest”

22d last night I saw Mr Lyons and asked him
if he had been summoned.—he replied not yet—that
he had recd a letter from Mr Henry stating that he intended to summon him and requesting him to
find out who did know any thing about the report, and
to send him their names in full. Mr Lyons says he does
not know any thing about it and is very sorry that
Mr Henry wrote to him. Mr Henry states that he intends
to bring suit against you for defamation, and that he
has obtained Counsel, but does not state how, altho
as I wrote above I heard it was H.P.—Mr Lyons can
send him no information, so for want of it he will not

be able to bring suit—I think this is the last you
will hear about it, the Gent evidently wanted to create
a sympathy, for himself in Charleston.

There is a private letter here lately recd from Cincinnati which
endorses all you said and more beside—I have not seen
it but Mr Valentine, has—he told me so.

I am anxious to learn if Solomon Solis has
arrived in Europe. I notice the arrival of the
vessels he went out in and dates to Asia 10 days after
his arrival but we have recd no letter and
Dear Sarah is very unhappy, if you know
the real state of his health please let me know
and enclose it to Mr Levin if unfavorable, as all
my letters are delivered at my Residence and I
do not wish my wife to be too suddenly informed of
any ill news, which I hope there will be no occasion for
